query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 Poi che la carità del natio loco 2 mi strinse, raunai le fronde sparte 3 e rende’le a colui, ch’era già fioco.
query.result:
**English:**
1 After the love of my native place 2 constrained me, I gathered the scattered leaves 3 and returned them to him who was already faint.
**Old English:**
1 Þa ða ðære stowe lufu 2 me geband, ða gegaderode ic ða toworpenan leaf, 3 and agef ðam ðe wæs ða gewanod.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
4 Indi venimmo al fine ove si parte 5 lo secondo giron dal terzo, e dove 6 si vede di giustizia orribil arte.
query.result:
**English:**
4 Then we came to the end where one departs 5 from the second circle to the third, and where 6 one sees the horrible art of justice.
**Old English:**
4 Þa com we to ðæm ende ðær man sceal 5 of ðæm oðrum hringe to ðæm ðriddan gân, and ðær 6 man mæg geseon ðære rihtwisnesse egeslice cræftas.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 A ben manifestar le cose nove, 8 dico che arrivammo ad una landa 9 che dal suo letto ogne pianta rimove.
query.result:
**English:**
7 To manifest the new things clearly, 8 I say that we arrived at a plain 9 that banished every plant from its bed.
**Old English:**
7 To ðære niwan ðingum rihtlice secgan, 8 ic secge ðæt we comon to anum felde 9 ðe ælce plantan of hire bedde adræfde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 La dolorosa selva l’è ghirlanda 11 intorno, come ’l fosso tristo ad essa; 12 quivi fermammo i passi a randa a randa.
query.result:
**English:**
10 The sorrowful wood is a garland 11 around it, like the sad moat to it; 12 there we stopped our steps, side by side.
**Old English:**
10 Se wædla wudu is wyrtruma 11 ymbe ðone, swa ðæt wætre ðone wudu utan ymbclyppað; 12 ðær we ða færelde feorðum samod.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 Lo spazzo era una rena arida e spessa, 14 non d’altra foggia fatta che colei 15 che fu da’ piè di Caton già soppressa.
query.result:
**English:**
13 The ground was a dry and thick sand, 14 made in no other way than that 15 which was once trodden down by Cato's feet.
**Old English:**
13 Se wæs ðæs wudu grund wederleas and dreorig, 14 næfre nænig mon ðær ðurh ne com, 15 swa hit ðuhte ðam ðe ðær ðurh sceolde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 O vendetta di Dio, quanto tu dei 17 esser temuta da ciascun che legge 18 ciò che fu manifesto a li occhi mei!
19 D’anime nude vidi molte gregge 20 che piangean tutte assai miseramente, 21 e parea posta lor diversa legge.
query.result:
**English:**
16 O vengeance of God, how much you should be 17 feared by everyone who reads 18 what was revealed to my eyes!
19 I saw many flocks of naked souls 20 who were all weeping very miserably, 21 and it seemed that different laws had been imposed on them.
**Old English:**
16 Eala, Godes wracu, hu ðu scealt 17 beon geondrysod fram æghwylcum men 18 ðæt ðæt ðinum eagum wæs gesyne!
19 Ic geseah sawla fela nacodne heap 20 wepan wælgrimme, 21 and him wæs gedæled sundor æghwylc.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 Supin giacea in terra alcuna gente, 23 alcuna si sedea tutta raccolta, 24 e altra andava continüamente.
query.result:
**English:**
22 Some people lay flat on the ground, 23 others sat huddled together, 24 and still others walked about incessantly.
**Old English:**
22 Sum wæs licgende on ðære eorðan, 23 sum sæt and wæs eal geðuht, 24 and sum eode swiðe fæste.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Quella che giva ’ntorno era più molta, 26 e quella men che giacëa al tormento, 27 ma più al duolo avea la lingua sciolta.
query.result:
**English:**
25 She who went around was more numerous, 26 and she who lay in torment was less, 27 but she had her tongue more loosed to grief.
**Old English:**
25 Seo ðe ymb eode wæs mare, 26 and seo ðe læg on ðam ðreage wæs læsse, 27 ac heo hæfde ðone tungan mare to ðam heofunge.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 Sovra tutto ’l sabbion, d’un cader lento, 29 piovean di foco dilatate falde, 30 come di neve in alpe sanza vento.
query.result:
**English:**
28 Over all the sand, with a slow descent, 29 fell dilated flakes of fire, 30 like snow in the Alps without wind.
**Old English:**
28 Ofer eall ðone sand, mid slæpendre hryre, 29 feollon ða fyres ða geondwlitan flocan, 30 swa swa snaw on muntum butan winde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 Quali Alessandro in quelle parti calde 32 d’Indïa vide sopra ’l süo stuolo 33 fiamme cadere infino a terra salde,
34 per ch’ei provide a scalpitar lo suolo 35 con le sue schiere, acciò che lo vapore 36 mei si stingueva mentre ch’era solo:
37 tale scendeva l’etternale ardore; 38 onde la rena s’accendea, com’ esca 39 sotto focile, a doppiar lo dolore.
query.result:
**English:**
31 Like Alexander in those hot regions 32 of India saw upon his troop 33 flames falling steadily to the ground,
34 so that he ordered his men to stamp on the ground 35 with their feet, so that the vapor 36 might be extinguished while it was still alone:
37 in such a way the eternal heat descended; 38 so that the sand was kindled, like tinder 39 under a flint, to double the pain.
**Old English:**
31 Swa swa Alexander on ðam hatan lande 32 on ðam Indea ofer his here 33 fyrene feollan fæste on eorðan,
34 ðæt he het his werod ðone wælgrimman grund 35 tredan mid fotum, ðæt ðæs fyres blæst 36 ðy sel mæge geswencan ða hwile ðe hit ana wære:
37 swa ðær ofdune ðæs ecan lig; 38 ðær ða ða sandas swæledon, swa ðær swefel 39 byrneð on fyre, ðæt ða witu twyfealdan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 Sanza riposo mai era la tresca 41 de le misere mani, or quindi or quinci 42 escotendo da sé l’arsura fresca.
query.result:
**English:**
40 Without rest was ever the throng 41 of the wretched hands, now here now there 42 shaking off from them the fresh burning.
**Old English:**
40 Butan reste wæs simle ðæt gedreag 41 ðæra wreccea handa, nu her nu ðær 42 asceacende him ða niwan bryne.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 I’ cominciai: «Maestro, tu che vinci 44 tutte le cose, fuor che ’ demon duri 45 ch’a l’intrar de la porta incontra uscinci,
46 chi è quel grande che non par che curi 47 lo ’ncendio e giace dispettoso e torto, 48 sì che la pioggia non par che ’l marturi?».
query.result:
**English:**
43 I began: "Master, you who conquer 44 all things, except for the stubborn demons 45 who came out to meet us at the entrance of the gate,
46 who is that great one who does not seem to care 47 about the fire and lies scornful and twisted, 48 so that the rain does not seem to torment him?"
**Old English:**
43 Ic ongan ða: "Lareow, ðu ðe ofercumes 44 ealle ðing, buton ða deofolheardan 45 ðe us on gean eodon æt ðære geate,
46 hwa is se mæra ðe ne recð 47 ðæs ligges and ðær licð lað and lyte, 48 ðæt ðone ren ne mæg geræcan?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 E quel medesmo, che si fu accorto 50 ch’io domandava il mio duca di lui, 51 gridò: «Qual io fui vivo, tal son morto.
query.result:
**English:**
49 And that same one, who had noticed 50 that I was asking my guide about him, 51 cried out: "As I was alive, so I am dead.
**Old English:**
49 And se ylca, ðe ðær geworhte 50 ðæt ic frægn minne heretogan be him, 51 cleopode: "Swa ic wæs lyfigende, swa ic eom dead.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 Se Giove stanchi ’l suo fabbro da cui 53 crucciato prese la folgore aguta 54 onde l’ultimo dì percosso fui;
55 o s’elli stanchi li altri a muta a muta 56 in Mongibello a la focina negra, 57 chiamando “Buon Vulcano, aiuta, aiuta!”,
58 sì com’ el fece a la pugna di Flegra, 59 e me saetti con tutta sua forza: 60 non ne potrebbe aver vendetta allegra».
query.result:
**English:**
52 If Jove wearies his smith from whom 53 in anger he took the sharp thunderbolt 54 with which I was struck on my last day;
55 or if he wearies the others in turn 56 at the black forge in Mongibello, 57 calling out “Good Vulcan, help, help!”,
58 just as he did at the battle of Phlegra, 59 and he shot me with all his strength: 60 he could not have a joyful vengeance.
**Old English:**
52 Gif Iupiter gewyrðeð his smið, fram ðæm 53 yrreful he genam ðone sceaðan lige, 54 mid ðæm ic on ðam æftran dæge gewundod wearð;
55 oððe gif he gewyrðeð ða oðre on gebyrdum 56 on ðam sweartan swege on Mongibelle, 57 clipiende “Wulcan, wel, wel!”,
58 swa swa he dyde on ðære gefeohte æt Fleogran, 59 and me mid ealre mihte his strælum gesceat: 60 ne mihte he næfre habban þæs wraðe gewrixle.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 Allora il duca mio parlò di forza 62 tanto, ch’i’ non l’avea sì forte udito: 63 «O Capaneo, in ciò che non s’ammorza
64 la tua superbia, se’ tu più punito; 65 nullo martiro, fuor che la tua rabbia, 66 sarebbe al tuo furor dolor compito».
query.result:
**English:**
61 Then my leader spoke with such force 62 that I had never heard him so strong: 63 "O Capaneus, in that your pride is not quenched, 64 you are punished all the more; 65 no torment, except your own rage, 66 would be sufficient pain for your狂怒."
**Old English:**
61 Þa min wordfrumælum wordum mælde 62 swiðe, swa ic næfre ær ne gehørde: 63 "Eala Capaneus, on ðæm ðe ne mæg 64 ðin ofermod aweaxan, ðu eart ðy swiðor 65 gewrecen; nis nan wite, buton ðinre rasnesse, 66 ðe mæg ðinum yrmðe efenlic ðyncan."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 Poi si rivolse a me con miglior labbia, 68 dicendo: «Quei fu l’un d’i sette regi 69 ch’assiser Tebe; ed ebbe e par ch’elli abbia
70 Dio in disdegno, e poco par che ’l pregi; 71 ma, com’ io dissi lui, li suoi dispetti 72 sono al suo petto assai debiti fregi.
query.result:
**English:**
67 Then he turned to me with a more gentle expression, 68 saying: "That was one of the seven kings 69 who besieged Thebes; and he had and seems to still have
70 God in disdain, and he seems to care little for Him; 71 but, as I told him, his acts of contempt 72 are to his breast quite suitable ornaments.
**Old English:**
67 Þa gewende he to me mid betere bleo, 68 cwæð: "Þes wæs an ðara seofon cyninga 69 ðe ða burh beheoldon; and he hæfde and ðinceð ðæt he hæbbe
70 God on andsware, and lyt ðinceð ðæt he hine weorðige; 71 ac, swa swa ic him sæde, his yrmða 72 syndon to his breostum swiðe geðafenlice wrixl."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 Or mi vien dietro, e guarda che non metti, 74 ancor, li piedi ne la rena arsiccia; 75 ma sempre al bosco tien li piedi stretti».
query.result:
**English:**
73 Now come behind me, and take care not to put 74 your feet again in the burning sand; 75 but keep them always close to the wood».
**Old English:**
73 Nu me folgað, and warniað ðæt ge ne setton, 74 eft, eowre fét on ða hatan sond; 75 ac healdað eowre fét simle fæste wið ðone wudu».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 Tacendo divenimmo là ’ve spiccia 77 fuor de la selva un picciol fiumicello, 78 lo cui rossore ancor mi raccapriccia.
query.result:
**English:**
76 In silence we came to where a little stream 77 flowed out of the forest, 78 the redness of which still horrifies me.
**Old English:**
76 Þa weard ic dumba and ðær we comon 77 ut of ðam wuda to anum lytlan wætere, 78 ðæs readnes me gyt ðone ræd onwecð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 Quale del Bulicame esce ruscello 80 che parton poi tra lor le peccatrici, 81 tal per la rena giù sen giva quello.
query.result:
**English:**
79 Like a stream that flows from the Bulicame, 80 which the sinners then divide among themselves, 81 so did that stream flow down over the sand.
**Old English:**
79 Swa swa ðæs Bulican stream of ðære byrne 80 ðe ða synfullan ða betwux him todælað, 81 swa ðurh ðone sand ðær ofan feoll ðæt wæter.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 Lo fondo suo e ambo le pendici 83 fatt’ era ’n pietra, e ’ margini dallato; 84 per ch’io m’accorsi che ’l passo era lici.
query.result:
**English:**
82 Its bottom and both its slopes 83 were made of stone, and the margins at the sides; 84 because of which I realized that the passage was narrow.
**Old English:**
82 His botm and eiðer of his sidan 83 wæron geworhte of stane, and ða margan be healfe; 84 for ði ic ongeat ðæt ðæt fæð wæs enge.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 «Tra tutto l’altro ch’i’ t’ho dimostrato, 86 poscia che noi intrammo per la porta 87 lo cui sogliare a nessuno è negato,
88 cosa non fu da li tuoi occhi scorta 89 notabile com’ è ’l presente rio, 90 che sovra sé tutte fiammelle ammorta».
query.result:
**English:**
85 “Among all the other things that I have shown you, 86 since we entered through the gate 87 whose threshold is denied to no one,
88 what thing has not been seen by your eyes 89 as remarkable as the present stream, 90 which quenches all flames above it”?
**Old English:**
85 “Betwux eallum ðam ðe ic ðe hæbbe gecyðed, 86 siððan we in eodon ðurh ða geat 87 ðæs ðyrscold ðe nænigum nis forwyrned,
88 hwæt nære ðinum eagum gesyne 89 wundorlicor ðonne ðeos ea is, 90 ðe ofer hyre sylfe ealle legas acwenð”?

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 Queste parole fuor del duca mio; 92 per ch’io ’l pregai che mi largisse ’l pasto 93 di cui largito m’avëa il disio.
query.result:
**English:**
91 These words came from my leader; 92 therefore I begged him to grant me the food 93 for which he had given me the desire.
**Old English:**
91 Þas word cwæð min latteow; 92 forðæm ic hine bæd ðæt he me sealde ðone mete 93 ðæs ðe he me ær ðone willan sealde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 «In mezzo mar siede un paese guasto», 95 diss’ elli allora, «che s’appella Creta, 96 sotto ’l cui rege fu già ’l mondo casto.
query.result:
**English:**
94 “In the middle of the sea sits a ruined land,” 95 he said then, “which is called Crete, 96 under whose king the world was once pure.
**Old English:**
94 “On middes sæ swaðe weste land,” 95 cwæð he ða, “ðæt is Creða nemned, 96 under ðæs cyninges ðe wæs geond ða woruld clæne.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 Una montagna v’è che già fu lieta 98 d’acqua e di fronde, che si chiamò Ida; 99 or è diserta come cosa vieta.
query.result:
**English:**
97 There is a mountain that once was joyful 98 with water and leaves, which was called Ida; 99 now it is deserted like something old and worn out.
**Old English:**
97 Is þær an munt ðe wæs iu mære 98 mid wætere and mid wudu, ðe man Idan nemde; 99 nu is weste geworden swa wudu eald.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 Rëa la scelse già per cuna fida 101 del suo figliuolo, e per celarlo meglio, 102 quando piangea, vi facea far le grida.
query.result:
**English:**
100 Rhea chose it as a safe cradle 101 for her son, and to better conceal him, 102 when he cried, she had shouts made.
**Old English:**
100 Rēa ðā gescēaf for cræte getīðum 101 hyre bearn geceas, and for ðȳ beteran hyde, 102 ðā hē wēop, hēo hēt wræclīc wop gewyrcan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 Dentro dal monte sta dritto un gran veglio, 104 che tien volte le spalle inver’ Dammiata 105 e Roma guarda come süo speglio.
query.result:
**English:**
103 Within the mountain stands a great old man, 104 who turns his back ten times toward Damietta 105 and looks at Rome as if it were his mirror.
**Old English:**
103 Binnon ðæm munte stondeð a mycel eald mon, 104 ðe hæfð tyn siðan ongean Damyatam, 105 and biðeð Rome swa swa his spegel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 Ciascuna parte, fuor che l’oro, è rotta 113 d’una fessura che lagrime goccia, 114 le quali, accolte, fóran quella grotta.
query.result:
**English:**
112 Every part, except the gold, is broken 113 by a fissure that drips tears, 114 which, collected, formed that stream.
**Old English:**
112 Ælc dæl, būton ðæt gold, is tobrocen 113 ðurh ða clifu ðe ða tearas wepeð, 114 ða ðær gegaderode wæron, ða ða græf wæron.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 Lor corso in questa valle si diroccia; 116 fanno Acheronte, Stige e Flegetonta; 117 poi sen van giù per questa stretta doccia,
118 infin, là ove più non si dismonta, 119 fanno Cocito; e qual sia quello stagno 120 tu lo vedrai, però qui non si conta».

Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 E io a lui: «Se ’l presente rigagno 122 si diriva così dal nostro mondo, 123 perché ci appar pur a questo vivagno?».
query.result:
**English:**
121 And I to him: "If this present stream 122 flows down thus from our world, 123 why does it appear to us only at this boundary?"
**Old English:**
121 And ic to him: "Gif ðeos ðis stream ryneð 122 ðus of ðissum weorulde, 123 hwi sceal he ðonne æt ðissum mere æteowian?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 Ed elli a me: «Tu sai che ’l loco è tondo; 125 e tutto che tu sie venuto molto, 126 pur a sinistra, giù calando al fondo,
127 non se’ ancor per tutto ’l cerchio vòlto; 128 per che, se cosa n’apparisce nova, 129 non de’ addur maraviglia al tuo volto».
query.result:
**English:**
124 And he to me: "You know that the place is round; 125 and although you have come a long way, 126 always to the left, descending down to the bottom,
127 you have not yet circled the entire circumference; 128 therefore, if something new appears to us, 129 it should not cause wonder on your face."
**Old English:**
124 And he to me: "Þu wast ðæt se stede is ymbren; 125 and ðeah ðu sie gecumen swiðe feor, 126 symle on ða wynstran healfe, niðer stigende to ðam grunde,
127 ne eart ðu gyt ðurh ealne ðone hring becumen; 128 for ði, gif ðær ænig ðing us wundrað, 129 hit ne ðearf ðin andwlita wundrian."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 E io ancor: «Maestro, ove si trova 131 Flegetonta e Letè? ché de l’un taci, 132 e l’altro di’ che si fa d’esta piova».
query.result:
**English:**
130 And I again: "Master, where is 131 Phlegethon and Lethe? For you are silent about one, 132 and you say that the other is made from this rain."
**Old English:**
130 And ic ða eft: "Lareow, hwær bið 131 Flegeton and Lethe? forðæm ðu ðæs anes suigest, 132 and ðu segst ðæt ðæt oder bið geworht of ðissum regne."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
133 «In tutte tue question certo mi piaci», 134 rispuose, «ma ’l bollor de l’acqua rossa 135 dovea ben solver l’una che tu faci.
query.result:
**English:**
133 "In all your questions you certainly please me," 134 he replied, "but the boiling of the red water 135 should have solved the one that you are asking.
**Old English:**
133 "On eallum ðinum andsware ðu me gecwemest," 134 he andwyrde, "ac ðæs hatan wæteres bryne 135 sceolde ðone an ðe ðu fregnest gefremman.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
136 Letè vedrai, ma fuor di questa fossa, 137 là dove vanno l’anime a lavarsi 138 quando la colpa pentuta è rimossa».
query.result:
**English:**
136 You will see Lethe, but outside of this ditch, 137 where the souls go to wash themselves 138 when the guilt of sin is removed.
**Old English:**
136 Lete ðu gesihst, ac hit ofer ðisse græfe, 137 ðær ða sawla baðað syndige, 138 ðonne ða synna sint afworpen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
139 Poi disse: «Omai è tempo da scostarsi 140 dal bosco; fa che di retro a me vegne: 141 li margini fan via, che non son arsi,
142 e sopra loro ogne vapor si spegne».
query.result:
**English:**
139 Then he said: "O man, it is time to leave 140 the wood; see that you follow me: 141 the edges make a path, for they are not burned,
142 and every vapor is quenched upon them."
**Old English:**
139 ða cwæð he: "Ðu scealt nu ðone wudu forlætan, 140 folgað me: ða margan doð ðe weg, ða ne beoð forburnene,
141 and ðær ofer ælc wæta gewited."
